unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I wanted to share my experience, as a first-time mom, navigating the world of pediatric care in India. It's been a journey, let me tell you!
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I wanted to share my experience, as a first-time mom, navigating the world of pediatric care in India. It's been a journey, let me tell you!

unnormalised: Finding a good pediatrician in Mumbai felt like searching for a needle in a haystack, tbh. Everyone had different opinions, and the sheer number of options was overwhelming. Finally, after asking around in my mommy group, I settled on Dr. Meena Sharma at Lilavati Hospital. She's supposed to be really good with newborns, and her clinic is close to my place in Bandra.
normalised: Finding a good pediatrician in Mumbai felt like searching for a needle in a haystack, to be honest. Everyone had different opinions, and the sheer number of options was overwhelming. Finally, after asking around in my mommy group, I settled on Doctor Meena Sharma at Lilavati Hospital. She's supposed to be really good with newborns, and her clinic is close to my place in Bandra.

unnormalised: The first few weeks were a blur of feeding schedules, diaper changes, and endless crying (mostly from me!). Little Aarav had jaundice, and Dr. Sharma recommended phototherapy for 48 hrs. Seeing my tiny baby under those blue lights was so scary, but Dr. Sharma explained everything so calmly and put my mind at ease.

Little Aarav had jaundice, and Doctor Sharma recommended phototherapy for forty eight hours. Seeing my tiny baby under those blue lights was so scary, but Doctor Sharma explained everything so calmly and put my mind at ease.

unnormalised: One thing I quickly learned is that Indian pediatricians often have different approaches than what you read online. For example, my grandmother kept insisting I give Aarav "ghutti" (herbal concoction) for his digestion. Dr. Sharma gently but firmly advised against it, saying it's not recommended by modern medicine and can even be harmful. Phew!

unnormalised: Navigating vaccinations was another challenge. The schedule is a bit different here, with BCG, DPT, OPV, and Hep B all crammed into the first few months. Plus, there are optional vaccines like Rotavirus and PCV which can be expensive. Dr. Sharma helped me prioritize based on Aarav's individual needs and my budget. Costs around Rs. 2500 each!
normalised: Navigating vaccinations was another challenge. The schedule is a bit different here, with B-C-G, D-P-T, O-P-V, and Hep B all crammed into the first few months. Plus, there are optional vaccines like Rotavirus and P-C-V which can be expensive. Doctor Sharma helped me prioritize based on Aarav's individual needs and my budget. Costs around rupees two thousand five hundred each!

unnormalised: I also found that Indian pediatricians are more likely to prescribe antibiotics than their counterparts in the West. When Aarav had a bad cough and cold at 3 months, Dr. Sharma prescribed Amoxicillin for 5 days. I was a bit hesitant, but she assured me it was necessary to prevent a secondary infection.

unnormalised: Another tip I picked up: don't be afraid to prepone appointments! When Aarav developed a fever of 102Â°F on a Sunday, I called Dr. Sharma's clinic and they squeezed me in for an emergency appointment. It's so important to have a pediatrician who's accessible when you need them most. Plus, get ready to wait in line! The waiting room at Lilavati is always packed with anxious parents and crying babies. Arrive at least 30 mins early!

unnormalised: Overall, my experience with pediatric care in India has been positive. It's a different system, but with a little research and a good pediatrician, you can ensure your little one gets the best possible care. Remember, every baby is different, and what works for one might not work for another. Trust your instincts, ask questions, and don't be afraid to seek a second opinion if needed. And most importantly, enjoy this precious time with your little one!
